text.div:
NameFlagsCard.TypeDescription & Constraints
Immunization 0..*Argonaut Immunization Profile
status S1..1codeBinding: Argonaut Immunization Status (required)
date S1..1dateTime
vaccineCode SI1..1CodeableConceptVaccine Product Type (bind to CVX)
Binding: Vaccine Administered Value Set (extensible)
arg-1: SHOULD have a translation to the to the NDC value set
patient S1..1Reference(Argonaut Patient Profile)
wasNotGiven S1..1boolean
reported S1..1boolean

Documentation for this format

element.name: Immunization
element.definition: Describes the event of a patient being administered a vaccination or a record of a vaccination as reported by a patient, a clinician or another party and may include vaccine reaction information and what vaccination protocol was followed.

constraint.human: If immunization was administered (wasNotGiven=false) then explanation.reasonNotGiven SHALL be absent.
If immunization was not administred (wasNotGiven=true) then there SHALL be no reaction nor explanation.reason present

element.name: Immunization.id
element.definition: The logical id of the resource, as used in the URL for the resource. Once assigned, this value never changes.
element.comments: The only time that a resource does not have an id is when it is being submitted to the server using a create operation. Bundles always have an id, though it is usually a generated UUID.

element.name: Immunization.meta
element.definition: The metadata about the resource. This is content that is maintained by the infrastructure. Changes to the content may not always be associated with version changes to the resource.

element.name: Immunization.implicitRules
element.short: A set of rules under which this content was created
element.definition: A reference to a set of rules that were followed when the resource was constructed, and which must be understood when processing the content.
element.comments: Asserting this rule set restricts the content to be only understood by a limited set of trading partners. This inherently limits the usefulness of the data in the long term. However, the existing health eco-system is highly fractured, and not yet ready to define, collect, and exchange data in a generally computable sense. Wherever possible, implementers and/or specification writers should avoid using this element as much as possible.

element.name: Immunization.language
element.definition: The base language in which the resource is written.
element.comments: Language is provided to support indexing and accessibility (typically, services such as text to speech use the language tag). The html language tag in the narrative applies  to the narrative. The language tag on the resource may be used to specify the language of other presentations generated from the data in the resource  Not all the content has to be in the base language. The Resource.language should not be assumed to apply to the narrative automatically. If a language is specified, it should it also be specified on the div element in the html (see rules in HTML5 for information about the relationship between xml:lang and the html lang attribute).

element.name: Immunization.text
element.short: Text summary of the resource, for human interpretation
element.definition: A human-readable narrative that contains a summary of the resource, and may be used to represent the content of the resource to a human. The narrative need not encode all the structured data, but is required to contain sufficient detail to make it "clinically safe" for a human to just read the narrative. Resource definitions may define what content should be represented in the narrative to ensure clinical safety.
element.comments: Contained resources do not have narrative. Resources that are not contained SHOULD have a narrative.

element.name: Immunization.contained
element.definition: These resources do not have an independent existence apart from the resource that contains them - they cannot be identified independently, and nor can they have their own independent transaction scope.
element.comments: This should never be done when the content can be identified properly, as once identification is lost, it is extremely difficult (and context dependent) to restore it again.

element.name: Immunization.extension
element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the resource. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
element.comments: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

element.name: Immunization.modifierExtension
element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the resource, and that modifies the understanding of the element that contains it. Usually modifier elements provide negation or qualification. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. Applications processing a resource are required to check for modifier extensions.
element.comments: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

element.name: Immunization.identifier
element.definition: A unique identifier assigned to this immunization record.

element.name: Immunization.status
element.definition: Indicates the current status of the vaccination event.
element.comments: Will generally be set to show that the immunization has been completed.

element.name: Immunization.date
element.definition: Date vaccine administered or was to be administered.
element.comments: When immunizations are given a specific date and time should always be known.   When immunizations are patient reported, a specific date might not be known. Â Although partial dates are allowed, an adult patient might not be able to recall the year a childhood immunization was given.

element.name: Immunization.vaccineCode
element.definition: Vaccine that was administered or was to be administered.

constraint.human: SHOULD have a translation to the to the NDC value set

element.name: Immunization.patient
element.definition: The patient who either received or did not receive the immunization.

element.name: Immunization.wasNotGiven
element.short: Flag for whether immunization was given
element.definition: Indicates if the vaccination was or was not given.

element.name: Immunization.reported
element.definition: True if this administration was reported rather than directly administered.
element.comments: May need source of reported info (e.g. parent), but leave out for now.

element.name: Immunization.performer
element.definition: Clinician who administered the vaccine.

element.name: Immunization.requester
element.definition: Clinician who ordered the vaccination.
element.comments: Other participants - delegate to Provenance resource.

element.name: Immunization.encounter
element.definition: The visit or admission or other contact between patient and health care provider the immunization was performed as part of.

element.name: Immunization.manufacturer
element.definition: Name of vaccine manufacturer.

element.name: Immunization.location
element.definition: The service delivery location where the vaccine administration occurred.

mapping.map: RXA-27  (or RXA-11, deprecated as of v2.7)

element.name: Immunization.lotNumber
element.definition: Lot number of the  vaccine product.

element.name: Immunization.expirationDate
element.definition: Date vaccine batch expires.

element.name: Immunization.site
element.definition: Body site where vaccine was administered.

binding.description: The site at which the vaccine was administered

element.name: Immunization.route
element.definition: The path by which the vaccine product is taken into the body.

binding.description: The route by which the vaccine was administered

element.name: Immunization.doseQuantity
element.definition: The quantity of vaccine product that was administered.

element.name: Immunization.note
element.definition: Extra information about the immunization that is not conveyed by the other attributes.

element.name: Immunization.explanation
element.definition: Reasons why a vaccine was or was not administered.

element.name: Immunization.explanation.id
element.definition: unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references).

element.name: Immunization.explanation.extension
element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
element.comments: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

element.name: Immunization.explanation.modifierExtension
element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element, and that modifies the understanding of the element that contains it. Usually modifier elements provide negation or qualification. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. Applications processing a resource are required to check for modifier extensions.
element.comments: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

element.name: Immunization.explanation.reason
element.definition: Reasons why a vaccine was administered.

binding.description: The reason why a vaccine was administered

element.name: Immunization.explanation.reasonNotGiven
element.definition: Reason why a vaccine was not administered.

binding.description: The reason why a vaccine was not administered

element.name: Immunization.reaction
element.short: Details of a reaction that follows immunization
element.definition: Categorical data indicating that an adverse event is associated in time to an immunization.
element.comments: A reaction may be an indication of an allergy or intolerance and, if this is determined to be the case,  it should be recorded as a new [[[AllergyIntolerance]]] resource instance as most systems will not query against  past Immunization.reaction elements.

element.name: Immunization.reaction.id
element.definition: unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references).

element.name: Immunization.reaction.extension
element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
element.comments: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

element.name: Immunization.reaction.modifierExtension
element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element, and that modifies the understanding of the element that contains it. Usually modifier elements provide negation or qualification. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. Applications processing a resource are required to check for modifier extensions.
element.comments: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

element.name: Immunization.reaction.date
element.definition: Date of reaction to the immunization.

mapping.map: OBX-14 (ideally this would be reported in an IAM segment, but IAM is not part of the HL7 v2 VXU message - most likely would appear in OBX segments if at all)

element.name: Immunization.reaction.detail
element.definition: Details of the reaction.

element.name: Immunization.reaction.reported
element.definition: Self-reported indicator.

mapping.map: (no such concept seems to exist for allergy/adverse reaction in HL7 v2)

element.name: Immunization.vaccinationProtocol
element.definition: Contains information about the protocol(s) under which the vaccine was administered.

mapping.map: (HL7 v2 doesn't seem to provide for this)

element.name: Immunization.vaccinationProtocol.id
element.definition: unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references).

element.name: Immunization.vaccinationProtocol.extension
element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
element.comments: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

element.name: Immunization.vaccinationProtocol.modifierExtension
element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element, and that modifies the understanding of the element that contains it. Usually modifier elements provide negation or qualification. In order to make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. Applications processing a resource are required to check for modifier extensions.
element.comments: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

element.name: Immunization.vaccinationProtocol.doseSequence
element.definition: Nominal position in a series.

element.name: Immunization.vaccinationProtocol.description
element.definition: Contains the description about the protocol under which the vaccine was administered.

element.name: Immunization.vaccinationProtocol.authority
element.definition: Indicates the authority who published the protocol.  E.g. ACIP.

element.name: Immunization.vaccinationProtocol.series
element.definition: One possible path to achieve presumed immunity against a disease - within the context of an authority.

element.name: Immunization.vaccinationProtocol.seriesDoses
element.short: Recommended number of doses for immunity
element.definition: The recommended number of doses to achieve immunity.

element.name: Immunization.vaccinationProtocol.targetDisease
element.definition: The targeted disease.

binding.description: The disease target of the vaccination protocol

element.name: Immunization.vaccinationProtocol.doseStatus
element.short: Indicates if dose counts towards immunity
element.definition: Indicates if the immunization event should "count" against  the protocol.
element.comments: May need to differentiate between status declarations by a provider vs. a CDS engine.

binding.description: The status of the vaccination protocol (i.e. should this count)

element.name: Immunization.vaccinationProtocol.doseStatusReason
element.definition: Provides an explanation as to why an immunization event should or should not count against the protocol.

binding.description: The reason for the determining if a vaccination should count or why vaccination should not count.

constraint.human: SHOULD have a translation to the to the NDC value set
